annotation.text: Segment 1

Born in Prague on September 15, 1907.  Moved to the Sudeten in 1909 (then Austria).  Lived there until the German takeover.

Early life

Parents had linen/cotton factory.  Big house.  Sister died before concentration camp.  Parents fled to another Czech town in 1938.  Parents were religious, kept a kosher home.  I married a non-Jew; father didn't speak to me for one year.  It took a long time for my parents to accept.  They were very happy when my first child was born, they made her Jewish.

Had been sent by father to France to learn French- studied millinery, sister studied French.  Then to Vienna, business school in Germany.  Had small millinery business in father's house.  Gave up business when married.  Nice apartment.  When daughter born had a dog, bird, housekeeper, car- a nice life.
Segment 2

Husband was an importer of Persian carpets.  He came to Germany with a transport of children who had survived a Turkish massacre.  Came with about four sisters and brothers.  Never saw them again, because all placed in different foster homes.  He told me, gave me books- it was like the Jews- people killed, deported.  I liked him, was moved by his story, so we got married.

Parents sent me to Berlin before, to forget about him; parents wanted a rabbi relative to talk me out of it, but he didn't.

My grandmother died, and my mother claimed it was because she was upset about me, but I thinks it was old age.  But I postponed marriage because my father was sick.  I visited him every day in the hospital, even though he refused to speak to me.  Finally I did marry, and things got better after my daughter was born.  Later, after the German occupation of Czechoslovakia, my husband was able to smuggle out money for my parents, and they were very grateful to him.  Parents left Sudetenland to stay with uncle in Czech proper one year after me. I left after the "Grynspan Affair" (Kristallnacht).
Segment 3

Parents' house had been looted.  They damaged everything they could.  Husband protested, the officials said it was martial law.  Husband sure nothing could happen to us because he wasn't Jewish, but on Kristallnacht they were like animals- threw old Jews around, etc.  I didn't see it myself, I was afraid to leave my house.  They had harassed my maid, told her if she came out with a Jewish child they would hurt her.

Gestapo came into the house and took my husband until they got confirmation from Vienna that he wasn't a Jew.  Husband then realized the danger, had me and daughter smuggled into Czechoslovakia; he got permission to move our belongings, then joined us.  Were in the spa town with my parents.

Story of Lidice- whole town killed by Heydrich.  Heydrich was killed in Prague.  Father died of cancer, couldn't be in a regular hospital because he was a Jew.
Segment 4

Mother was called to the worst transport, called the "Heydrich transport."  Only ten survivors of thousands- taken to Maidanek.  

Mother's deportation- I was in the hospital because I had just given birth to my second child.  Five days after the child was born, mother went first to [Kolin?], a town from where shipped to camps- first to Terezin, then to Maidanek (near Lublin).  Mother in worst transport- told by a survivor that Jews had to run in circles while SS and SA shot them.  One man crawled out from under the dead but very few survivors.  Mother came to see me at the hospital on the last day and gave me her gold watch, and I gave her my watch.  Mother gave a Czech all her jewelry to hide but never got it back.  But a pastor hid jewelry for us and I got it back.  This pastor was so helpful to Jews, imprisoned by the Gestapo.

Leavetaking from mother.

There was nothing we could do.  I was undernourished, had scurvy.
Segment 5

Husband had to go to country every day to get milk for child, not enough rations, though husband and children got more.  I show ration card- for Jew.  I show yellow star, had to wear, and so did my "Jewish daughter."  This daughter was taunted in school, had to stop going.  When daughter was two years, three months old (1941), husband was ordered to another town.  Town was bombarded, husband ordered to clean up- special transport of Christian men married to Jewish women.  I wrote him.  My Jewish daughter and I were ordered to a labor camp.  He went to Gestapo headquarters in Prague to protest but was not received well, put in special transport to Germany as punishment- he had refused to divorce me.
Segment 6

Wore armband saying "Arbeitet fur."  He got very sick.  When recovered sent to another camp.  Then, nearly end of war, to a small camp in Czechoslovakia- Bischitz (Wischwitz) near [Benechau?].  I was ordered to give up my dog, because Jews were not allowed to have an animal.  For daughter's sake kept our dog, got another which they we give up.  I had to give up our furs, all valuables.

Labor camp in 1942.  Daughter was in children's camp, once ran away to me.  Jesli (child's camp).  Hagibor (my camp).  Went to camp by train at four o'clock in the morning (Jews not allowed on train during the day).  Daughter ran away to me, was allowed to talk to me, but we couldn't talk, just cried.
Segment 7

Then daughter had to go back to her camp.  I took care of sick people in labor camp.  Glad my husband didn't divorce her- another inmate, whose husband divorced her, was immediately shipped to Auschwitz and killed.  Happened often.  My camp was for Jewish women who were married to non-Jews.

Youngest daughter- was with a family in the same building where we had lived.  After war she didn't recognize me, it took a while for her to get attached to me again.

She recognized my husband, who had come back earlier, but was very sick, all skin and bones.  She was two years, three months old when neighbors took her.  She was happy there, but the night before I left I heard my daughter crying for many hours.  Had fallen and hit her head.  I left her when she was with pain.  Neighbors promised would take her to a doctor the next day. 

In labor camp- awakened at 3:30 AM for transport to Terezin- end of 1943.  Stood at railroad station until 10 AM.  1000 women in transport.
Segment 8

Arrived Terezin early morning- fortresses and small town.  People beaten to death in fortress.  I entered long hall, like catacomb, waited for card {I show the card}- no more name, got number.   Assigned to work cutting stones into small pieces {I show the stone}- for V.I.'s, insulation for the fighter planes.  Quota, if didn't meet didn't get bread.

?How/why did you keep the piece of mica?
I wanted to show to husband if he lived. I had more things, but they got lost: ghetto gold.  When ordered in big room I got nervous shock, so the doctor kept me for last of women on stretchers.  Handbags taken, sent to small room, stripped, searched for lice by men with flashlights.  Hot shower and sheet, through open yard to another building.  Eventually got clothes back.  First night on bloody, dirty mattress.
Segment 9

Next day on mattresses full of lice.  Sick shipped to Birkenau, Dachau, Auschwitz.  I was the only survivor of my family except two cousins who had left country before war.

Fate of older, "Jewish" daughter after I was sent to Terezin.  In Terezin you had to sign if you had children and tell their religion- I said daughters were Christian.  The pastor who had helped us before fought to have my daughter released from camp.  Got her out and took care of her until the end of the war.  Dr. Josef Jeschke- died a few years ago.  Pastor- kept writing each other.  He gave excellent sermons- I sent my daughters to Sunday school with husband.  I once told him if I were ever to give up being Jewish (which I never would), I would choose his religion- Protestant.  Was very helpful, after war very good to my whole family.

Terezin work- from barracks to [Bauschowitz?] for slave labor.  Bad conditions, hard to cut the stones, inhaled.
Segment 10

Thoughts walking to work- passed morgue barracks- I always cried, afraid my mother might be among them.  Until a woman told me if I cried, I'd never see my children again, so I stopped.  Traded bread for shoes.  Also packed belongings from transports in baskets, to be sent to Germany.  Mixed marriage prisoners could keep own clothes; other prisoners issued striped uniforms.

Before Terezin, didn't know what was happening.  Went from Prague about one hour by train to Limborg (transit camp) to pack the belongings.  Was very upset because I knew my mother and other relatives went the same way.
